maml:description.maml:para: Adds a role to a OneLogin user

Use Add-OneLoginUserRole to add one or more roles to a OneLogin user. To discover roles to add, use the Get-OneLoginRole command, and to find roles that the user already belongs to, use Get-OneLoginUserRole.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the OneLogin user that you'd like to add a role to.
Specifies the Id of the role you'd like to add.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 1 --------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Role = Get-OneLoginRole -Filter @{name = "Sales"} PS C:\> Get-OneLoginUser -Identity 12345678 | Add-OneLoginUserRole -RoleId $Role.id -Token $Token

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example demonstrates how to add a role to a user via the pipeline. Get-OneLoginUser returns a user by Id, and Add-OneLoginUserRole adds the role "Sales" to that user.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns all custom attribute names configured in a OneLogin account.
Returns all custom attribute names configured in a OneLogin account. Values for custom attributes are not returned - these are returned by the command Get-OneLoginUserCustomAttribute.

maml:Description.maml:para: A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will return the names of all custom attributes configured in your OneLogin account.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves events from a OneLogin account
Retrieves events such as logins, role assignments, and password resets from a OneLogin account.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a combination of event properties to filter on. The filter should be in the form of a hashtable with one or more property names as keys. Note that the filter values should always be strings, and can contain asterisks as wildcards. Acceptable keys are:
- client_id
- created_at
- directory_id
- event_type_id
- resolution
- user_id

Valid values for event_type_id are available in the enum "OneLogin.EventType." To find out how to use this enum to find the event id integer values, see the examples for this help topic by running: Get-Help -Name Get-OneLoginEvent -Examples
More information about possible event types can be found at https://developers.onelogin.com/api-docs/1/events/event-resource.
To learn more about hashtables, run the command:
Get-Help about_hash_tables
The earliest date for which to return events. This can be used with or without a filter. If you don't specify a filter, the -Since parameter will be required.
The latest date for which to return events. If you specify the -Since parameter but not the -Until parameter, this will have a value of the current date and time.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to use a filter to return all events for a specific user, identified by the user_id property.
This example shows how to retrieve events for a specific user and specific event type, a password change.
This example will return all events for a specific user that occured between 9/23/2016 and 9/24/2016.
This example will retrieve all events of any type between 9/23/2016 and 9/24/2016
This example will retrieve all events of type 'User_logged_in_to_app. Note the use of the enum "OneLogin.EventType" to calculate the numerical event id.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves groups from a OneLogin account.
Retrieves groups from a OneLogin account.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the numeric id of a OneLogin group. If you do not include this parameter, all available groups will be returned.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example returns all groups in the OneLogin account.
This example demonstrates how to use the -Identity parameter to return a single group object.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves roles from a OneLogin account.
Retrieves roles from a OneLogin account.

maml:Description.maml:para: You can use the -Filter parameter to search for roles matching values that you specify. A filter should be in the format of a PowerShell hashtable with one or more properties as keys. Note that the filter values should always be strings, and can contain asterisks as wildcards. Acceptable properties to filter on are:
- name
- id
To learn more about hashtables, run the following command:
Get-Help about_hash_tables
This parameter cannot be used with -Identity r -All
Specifies the numeric id of a OneLogin role.
Specifies tthat you would like to return all roles in your OneLogin account. This parameter cannot be used with -Filter or -Identity.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example returns all roles in the OneLogin account.
This example demonstrates how to use the -Identity parameter to return a single role object.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves users from a OneLogin account.
Retrieves users and their attributes from a OneLogin account.

maml:Description.maml:para: You can use the -Filter parameter to search for users matching values that you specify. A filter should be in the format of a PowerShell hashtable with one or more properties as keys. Note that the filter values should always be strings, and can contain asterisks as wildcards. Acceptable properties to filter on are:
- directory_id
- email
- external_id
- firstname
- manager_ad_id
- role_id
- samaccountname
- username
- userprincipalname
To learn more about hashtables, run the following command:
Get-Help about_hash_tables
This parameter cannot be used with -Identity or -All
Specifies the numeric id of a OneLogin user.
Specifies tthat you would like to return all roles in your OneLogin account. This parameter cannot be used with -Filter or -Identity.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example returns all users in the OneLogin account.
This example demonstrates how to use the -Identity parameter to return a single user object.
This example demonstrates how to use the -Filter parameter to return a single user by specifying an email address.
This example demonstrates how to use the -Filter parameter to return any users whose email address matches a wildcard string.
This example demonstrates how to use the -Filter parameter with more than one property.

maml:description.maml:para: Lists the OneLogin applications that a user has been granted access to.

Use Add-OneLoginUserRole to add one or more roles to a OneLoginLists the OneLogin applications that a user has been granted access to. These can be provisioned or personal applications and will include those provided manually or via roles and mappings.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the OneLogin user whose apps you'd like to query.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to retrieve all the applications granted to a OneLogin user.
This example shows how to retrieve all the applications granted to any OneLogin user whose email address begins with "Ronald".

maml:description.maml:para: Returns the OneLogin group that a user is a member of.
Returns the OneLogin group that a user is a member of. A user can only belong to one group, and this group membership determines which security policy the user is subject to.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the user whose group membership you'd like to discover.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to retrieve the group membership for a single user.
This example shows how to retrieve the group membership for multiple users.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns the OneLogin roles that have been assigned to a user.
Returns the OneLogin roles that have been assigned to a user. These roles may be assigned automatically via mappings, or manually assigned by an administrator.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the user whose role assignments you'd like to discover.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to retrieve the role assignments for a single user.
This example shows how to retrieve the role assignments for multiple users.

maml:description.maml:para: Locks out a OneLogin user for a specified period of time.
Locks out a OneLogin user for a specified period of time. While locked out, the user will not be able to sign in to OneLogin or provided applications.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the user who will be locked out.

Specifies the duration in minutes that the user will be locked out. If you do not specify a value, or if you specify zero, the lockout duration will be the value of the lockout duration in the user's security policy. If the user's security policy does not specify a lockout duration, and the value of -IntervalInMinutes is 0 or unspecified, the lockout will remain in effect until you unlock the user.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example demonstrates how to lock out a user for one hour.

maml:description.maml:para: Logs a user out of OneLogin
Logs a user out of any active OneLogin sessions and any applications provided via OneLogin.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the user who will be logged off.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

maml:description.maml:para: Refreshes a OneLogin API access token that is nearing expiration
Refreshes a OneLogin API access token that is nearing expiration. These tokens are passed to other commands in the OneLogin module.

In order to authenticate to the OneLogin API, you must first grant access by generating a credential pair in the OneLogin web interface. To generate an API credential, log in to your OneLogin tenant with an admin account and navigate to "Settings" > "API" and click "New Credential." Please note that your choice of credential type will affect what capabilities you are granted by the API.
Issued tokens are valid for 10 hours. Once you have been issued a refresh token, the original token is revoked and will no longer authenticate calls to the OneLogin API.

maml:Description.maml:para: The administrative region that your account exists in. Valid values are "us" and "eu."

Specifies whether you'd like to set this token as the default value for the -Token parameter of all OneLogin commands. If you select this option, any subsequent OneLogin commands will use this token without the need to specify the -Token parameter. Please note that this modifies the value of the automatic variable $PSDefaultParameterValues in your current PowerShell session.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 1 --------------
command:example.dev:code: PS c:\> $Credential = Get-Credential PS c:\> $Token = New-OneLoginToken -Credential $Credential -Region us PS c:\> $Token = New-OneLoginRefreshToken -Token $Token

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example demonstrates how to generate a OneLogin token and then refresh that token.

This example demonstrates how to refresh an existing OneLogin token and set it as the default token value for subsequent calls to OneLogin commands. This is recommended if you originally created the token using the -SetAsDefault switch.

maml:description.maml:para: Generates a OneLogin API access token
Generates a OneLogin API access token that can be passed to other commands in the OneLogin module.

In order to authenticate to the OneLogin API, you must first grant access by generating a credential pair in the OneLogin web interface. To generate an API credential, log in to your OneLogin tenant with an admin account and navigate to "Settings" > "API" and click "New Credential." Please note that your choice of credential type will affect what capabilities you are granted by the API.
Issued tokens are valid for 10 hours. If you'd like to refresh a token that is near to its' expiration, use the New-OneLoginRefreshToken command.

maml:Description.maml:para: The OAuth client ID and client secret associated with a OneLogin API credential. Use the client ID as the username and the client secret as the password. Instructions for obtaining a credential pair can be found here: https://developers.onelogin.com/api-docs/1/getting-started/working-with-api-credentials
The administrative region that your account exists in. Valid values are "us" and "eu."

Specifies whether you'd like to set this token as the default value for the -Token parameter of all OneLogin commands. If you select this option, any subsequent OneLogin commands will use this token without the need to specify the -Token parameter. Please note that this modifies the value of the automatic variable $PSDefaultParameterValues in your current PowerShell session.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 1 --------------
command:example.dev:code: PS c:\> $Credential = Get-Credential PS c:\> $Token = New-OneLoginToken -Credential $Credential -Region us

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example demonstrates how to save a credential object in a variable and pass that credential to New-OneLoginToken

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 2 --------------
command:example.dev:code: PS c:\> $Credential = Get-Credential PS c:\> New-OneLoginToken -Credential $Credential -Region us -SetAsDefault

dev:remarks.maml:para: In this example, we've created a OneLogin token and set it as the default token for all OneLogin commands. After this, the -Token parameter of the commands from the OneLogin module will not be required.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new user in your OneLogin account.
Logs a user out of any active OneLogin sessions and any applications provided via OneLogin.

maml:Description.maml:para: A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to create a new OneLogin user.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a user from your OneLogin account.
Removes a user from your OneLogin account.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a OneLogin user you'd like to remove.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to remove a OneLogin user. Note that you'll be prompted to confirm that you'd like to take this action.
This example shows how to remove a OneLogin user without being prompted for confirmation.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a custom attribute from a OneLogin user.
Removes a custom attribute from a OneLogin user.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a OneLogin user who you'd like to modify.

Specifies one or more custom attributes to remove. You can find a user's custom attributes with the Get-OneLoginUser command, and you can find all available custom attributes in your account with Get-OneLoginCustomAttribute.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to remove a custom attribute for a OneLogin user. Note that you'll be prompted to confirm that you'd like to take this action.
This example shows how to remove a custom attribute from a OneLogin user without being prompted for confirmation.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a role from a OneLogin user.
Removes a role from a OneLogin user.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a OneLogin user who you'd like to modify.
Specifies one or more roles that you'd like to remove by their numerical Id. These Ids can be found using the Get-OneLoginRole command.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to find a OneLogin role and remove that role from a user's list of assigned roles. Note that you'll be prompted to confirm that you'd like to take this action.
This example shows how to remove a role from a OneLogin user without being prompted for confirmation.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets attributes of a OneLogin user.
Sets or modifies attributes of an existing OneLogin user.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a OneLogin user who you'd like to modify.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows howto modify the department attribute for a OneLogin user.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the value of custom attributes.
Sets or modifies the value of custom attributes for a OneLogin user. Can also be used to add a custom attribute for a user.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a OneLogin user who you'd like to modify.

Specifies the custom attributes and their values that will be applied to the user. The value of this parameter argument should be in the form of a PowerShell hashtable, with the key representing the name of the custom attribute, and the value being the custom attribute's value.
A OneLogin API access token that provides authorization for a OneLogin account. To generate an access token, use the New-OneLoginToken command.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows howto modify the value of the employeeType custom attribute for a user.
